title: Silicon Motion Technology Corp (SIMO) Q1 2019 Earnings Call Transcript
callText:
Image source: The Motley Fool.

Silicon Motion Technology Corp  (NASDAQ:SIMO)Q1 2019 Earnings CallMay. 03, 2019, 8:00 a.m. ET
Contents:

Prepared Remarks
Questions and Answers
Call Participants

Prepared Remarks:
Operator
Ladies and gentlemen thank you for standing by and welcome to the Silicon Motion Technology Corporation First Quarter 2019 Earnings Conference Call. At this time all participants are in a listen-only mode.
This conference call contains forward-looking statements within the meaning of Section 27A of the Securities Act of 1933 and Section 21E of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 as amended. Such forward-looking statements include, without limitation, statements regarding trends in the semiconductor industry and our future results of operations, financial conditions and business prospects. Although such statements are based on our own information and information from other sources we believe to be reliable, you should not place undue reliance on them.
These statements involve risks and uncertainties and actual market trends and our results may differ materially from those expressed or implied in these forward-looking statements for a variety of reasons. Potential risks and uncertainties include, but are not limited to continued competitive pressure in the semiconductor industry and the effect of such pressure on prices; unpredictable changes in technology and consumer demand for multimedia consumer electronics; the state of and any change in our relationship with our major customers; and changes in political, economic, legal and social conditions in Taiwan.
For additional discussion of these risks and uncertainties and other factors, please see the documents we file from time to time with the Securities and Exchange Commission. We assume no obligation to update any forward-looking statements, which apply only as of the date of this conference call.
Today's call will include a question-and-answer session. (Operator Instructions) I must advise you that this conference is being recorded today Friday, 3rd of May 2019.
I would now like to hand the conference over to your first speaker today Mr. Chris Chaney, Director of Investor Relations and Strategy. Thank you. Please go ahead sir.
Christopher Chaney -- Director, Investor Relations & Strategy
Thank you Amber. Good morning everyone and welcome to Silicon Motion's First Quarter 2019 Financial Results Conference Call and Webcast. My name is Chris Chaney Director of Investor Relations. With me here is Wallace Kou, our President and CEO; and Riyadh Lai, our Chief Financial Officer.
Following my comments. Wallace will give a review of our key business developments and then Riyadh will discuss our first quarter results and our outlook. We will then conclude with a question and answer period. Before we get started, I'd like to remind you of our Safe Harbor policy, which was read at the start of this call. For a comprehensive overview of the risks involved in investing in our securities, please refer to our filings with the U.S. SEC.
For more details on our financial results, please refer to our press release, which was filed on Form 6-K after the close of the market yesterday. This webcast will be available for replay on our website, at www.siliconmotion.com, for a limited time.
To enhance investors' understanding of our ongoing economic performance, we will discuss non-GAAP information during this call. We use non-GAAP financial measures internally to evaluate and manage our operations. We have, therefore, chosen to provide this information to enable you to perform comparisons of our operating results in a manner similar to how we analyze our own operating results. The reconciliation of the GAAP to non-GAAP financial data can be found in our earnings release issued yesterday. We ask that you review it in conjunction with this call.
With that, I will now turn the call over to Wallace.
Wallace C. Kou -- President, Chief Executive Officer and Director
Thank you, Chris. Hello everyone and thank you for joining us today. I will first update you on our business and then Riyadh will review our financials and provide our outlook later on this call. For the first quarter, our sales from continuing operation of $89 million declined 23% sequentially. Including FCI, our sales were $95 million and had also declined 23% sequentially. Earnings per ADS for the quarter were $0.42.
Let me start with an update with our SSD controller. This quarter our SSD controller sales were flat sequentially, in line with what we had communicated to you three months ago. As previously discussed, while NAND prices have been falling sharply, which triggered an increase in demand for SSD. The reaction is not immediate, especially with OEM customers, where design, qualification, and testing processes would be extensive. Separately, when NAND prices are falling sharply, module makers face increased financial risk and so become more conservative in procuring NAND flash components and related controllers. This situation is now changing. Procurement of controllers for our NAND flash customers is beginning to step up because there's a need for new OEM program are starting to move into productions.
Also procurement of controller from our module maker customer is increasing as they are now receiving NAND flash from their supplier at a more attractive terms, which is leading to a rebound in their business activity. As we have been saying, ever since NAND supply and demand dynamic has started shifting from shortage to surplus and NAND pricing has reverted to its long term declining trend. Our business now files toward gross with the benefit of price elasticity of demand. Approximately $250 million client hard disk drives are still shipping annually. And over the next few years, as NAND prices fall further, most of these client HDD will be replaced by SSD.
Our pipeline of SSD controller projects with our NAND partners expanded further in this quarter. More and more importantly, interest in building SSD, especially for OEM applications and the interest in adopting more of our controller in this project from customer has increased meaningfully in recent months. Based on current design activity, we believe our market share is all the leading PC OEM will expand meaningfully by the end of this year.
We are excited that our SSD controller order momentum has started to pick up with both NAND flash and module maker customers. In the second quarter, we expect our SSD controller sales to grow approximately 25% quarter-over-quarter. While visibility for the balance of the year remain limited, we are expanding pipeline of SSD controller design wins, especially for SSD design for PC OEM, strongly position us for further growth. Let me, however, caution that while our near-term business momentum has improved our sales visibility into the second half year remain limited. While many of our business partners are expecting NAND prices to be stabilized are far more moderately in the second half of the year and demand remains like last year.
NAND flash maker continues to hold elevated level of inventory. NAND prices remain volatile and our customer could change business direction quickly. Our order book for the second half remains unclear and the rapidly changing market conditions could affect our business both positively and negatively. Our enterprise grade SSD controller remains on track to begin commercial production in the middle of the year. Commercial shipment of our enterprise SSD controller embedding our Shannon Open Channel NVMe SSD. I expect it to begin mid year. Additionally in the second half of this year, we are also expecting to begin initial low volume sale of our enterprise SSD controller to our few U.S. customers.
Turning into our eMMC plus UFS controllers, sales in this quarter were down about 45% sequentially. Our eMMC and UFS controllers have high exposure to the China market. According to the China Academy of Information and Communication Technology data, first quarter in mobile phones shipment volume in China were down 30% quarter-over-quarter. Our large eMMC NAND flash customer recently talked about their eMCP sales declined 32% in the first quarter, which is in line with the Chinese data. Additionally, our NAND side customer may have exited 2018 with slightly higher controller inventory which were consumed in the first quarter.
Based on our current order book, our eMMC plus UFS controller cell growth should be roughly flat in the second quarter. Looking into the second half of this year, we are expecting strong eMMC embedded memory build activity by Chinese module maker and strong UFS embedded memory cells by our NAND flash customer. We have a very clear market share leadership with module maker in China for eMMC. Our module maker customer who have been actively supporting for quite some time, have improved sourcing of NAND flash components specifically for building eMMC and have made good progress. Securing design win in Chinese smartphone OEM, we believe our UFS controller sales will grow further in the second half of the year, once our upgrade higher performance UFS 2.1 controller enter production.
Now let me discuss our SSD solution sales. In the first quarter, sale of our SSD solution fell about 40% sequentially, with both our Shannon and Ferri sales declining. Our Ferri product declined as expected. Our Shannon product declined worse than expected with the China's economy continued to soften, an Internet company reduced their operation and CapEx plan. As many of you know, several leading Chinese Internet companies including Tencent, JD.com and DB recently announced large lay offs. Our Shannon customers have been reducing SSD procurement plans. Our Open Channel SSD for both Alibaba and another BAT customers are expected to complete testing around the middle of this year and enter production in the third quarter. For full year 2019, we believe our SSD solution sale could fall over 10% this year due to China's soften economic and corresponding impact to its Internet ecosystems.
2019 remain a challenging year for us. Nevertheless, we feel better about our SSD controller growth outlook with strong near-term momentum and improving feedback from customers, for the balance of the year. We also feel better about our Chinese module maker customers entering into eMMC market with smartphone. Further growth of our UFS controller in the second half of the year and our Open Channel SSD project for the BAT continuing to track (inaudible) commercial production. On the other hand, we are feeling less confident about SSD solutions upside opportunity this year given MICO issue in China.
Now let me turn the call over to Riyadh to discuss our financial performance and more about outlook.
Riyadh Lai -- Chief Financial Officer
Thank you Wallace and hello everyone. I will summarize our financial results and then provide our outlook. Before I begin, I would like to reiterate that our comments today will focus primarily on non-GAAP results unless otherwise specifically noted. Please note that our non-GAAP excludes FCI, excluded to provide transparency to the performance of our continuing operations. A reconciliation of our GAAP to non-GAAP data is included with the earnings release issued yesterday.
In Q1, revenue decline 23% sequentially. Results for our three key products are as follows. SSD controller sales were flat sequentially and I would like to highlight that SSD controllers are now 55% of our total net sales. eMMC plus UFS controller sales declined about 45% and SSD solutions declined about 40%. Gross margins in Q1 were flat sequentially at 50.2%. Gross margins were flat because margin upside from our higher sales mix of higher gross margin controllers were offset by meaningful decreases in gross margins for our SSD solutions and non storage products. Controller gross margins were stable quarter-over-quarter.
Operating expenses in Q1 rose significantly to $28.6 million from $27.5 million in the previous quarter, due primarily to higher R&D spending expenditures. Operating margin in Q1 declined to 18% from 26.5% in the previous quarter, due to declining sales and higher operating expenses. Our effective tax rate in Q1 was 14% compared to 8% due to one off tax benefits in the previous quarter.
Earnings per ADS in Q1 declined to $0.42 from $0.82 in the previous quarter. Stock-based compensation in our operating expenses, which we exclude from our non-GAAP results, were $4.1 million in Q1 compared to $11.9 million in the prior quarter due to seasonal timing of RSU awards.
We had $281 million of cash, cash equivalents, and short term investments at the end of Q4 -- at the end of Q1, down $8 million from the prior quarter. Cash flow from operations generated $13.3 million in Q1. This quarter we had over $1 million of CapEx, primarily for routine purchases of software and design tools. In late February, we paid $11 million of dividends to shareholders, the second $0.30 per ADS quarterly installment of our annual $1.20 per ADS dividend that was announced in October of last year. We did not repurchase any shares this quarter due to limited business visibility for the full year.
Now let me turn to our Q2 and full-year 2019 outlook. In Q2, we expect revenue to increase 10% to 20% sequentially, driven by our SSD controllers. As discussed by Wallace, we continue to have limited sales visibility for the second half of this year and until we see more concrete procurement's forecast from customers, we do not believe it is appropriate to provide false precision implied by a quantified guidance. Until we have better business visibility, we believe that it is likely that full-year revenue could be approximately similar to last year.
Let me provide color on our key products. In Q2, we expect our SSD controller sales to grow roughly 25% sequentially. While we do not have clear order visibility for the second half of this year, we nevertheless believe it is more than likely that our SSD controller sales would continue growing strongly through the balance of the year. We expect eMMC plus UFS controller sales growth to be roughly flat in Q2. In the second half of this year, we are expecting growth from both our China module maker, eMMC sales, and our flash customers UFS sales. Our legacy Hynix eMMC programs could continue at the current level for the balance of the year. We expect our SSD Solutions sales growth to be flat in Q2 and grow in the second half as our Shannon open-channel SSD solutions enter commercial production. For full year 2019, we believe that our SSD solution sales could fall over 10%.
Q2 gross margin is expected to be between 48.5% and 50.5%. While our mix of higher gross margin controller sales will increase in Q2, we are expecting our controller gross margins to temporarily decline, as we share some of our long term strategic partners current financial pain. For the full year, if our product mix remains the same as 2018, our gross margins should remain unchanged year-over-year. Since our business is dynamic it is likely that our product mix will change each quarter. Q2 operating margin is expected to be between 18.6% to 21.6%. We expect Q2 operating expense to be roughly similar to the previous quarter.
For the full year, we expect operating margin to remain the same as 2018 if gross margins were to remain unchanged year-over-year. We expect to continue to tightly managing operating expenses this year. Stock-based compensation in Q2 is expected to be in the range of $0.4 million to $0.5 million and for the full year to be slightly less than 2018. Tax rate in Q2 is expected to be approximately 15% and for the full year to be approximately 15% our normal tax rate.
This concludes our prepared remarks. We will now open the call to your questions.





Questions and Answers:
Operator
Thank you. (Operator Instructions) Your first question comes from the line of Karl Ackerman from Cowen. Please go ahead.
Karl Ackerman -- Cowen -- Analyst
Hi, good afternoon everyone, can you hear me?
Wallace C. Kou -- President, Chief Executive Officer and Director
Yes.
Karl Ackerman -- Cowen -- Analyst
Great. Riyadh or Wallace, if I could just go back to your full year outlook, it doesn't seem to imply a fairly sizable ramp in second half of '19. You indicated how both revenue and margins would be, of course relatively, similar on a year-over-year basis assuming no product mix change. Albeit, you just mentioned that product mix will change on a quarterly basis from here. So I guess, I think -- one of the biggest variables that impacts perhaps your overall outlook is the Open Channel and customer SSD business. So perhaps you could elaborate on the visibility you have with your -- both customer SSD and Open Channel controller opportunities to the BAT providers, not just in the June quarter but also the trajectory in the second half, given fairly depressed levels today. And I guess what gives you confidence that that segment's growth came advanced and through in second second half of '19? How do we think about the progress and qualification of that program? Thank you.
Wallace C. Kou -- President, Chief Executive Officer and Director
So we are working closely with two of our BAT customers in China -- we have been working together for almost more than one year. The progress needed a tremendous effort from both parties and see hyperscaler need to also a tremendous software development in their side. We have a tremendous software development to fine tune for different business model and the workload. And we are on track. Currently, it's in the final stage of qualification in the real workload and we believe that will be done by end of the June or mid of June and product will be moving to production by beginning of third quarter. So that confident we have is that all of the (inaudible) our hands but we have to qualify the final stage of the real workload test in their real server systems.
Karl Ackerman -- Cowen -- Analyst
Got it. That's helpful. I guess for my follow up, if I may. On your mobile business, I know you're in a period of transition from growing as a US-based customer, while also continuing to service the Korean customers legacy tech nodes, at the same time two (ph) issues appear to be playing from the segment with their high levels of controller inventory cross-channel, handset supply chain? And perhaps the second being that Samsung wants to aggressively attack the mobile market in the second half. Given many of these moving parts, how do we think about the linearity of the smartphone controller business for the balance of '19? Thank you.
Wallace C. Kou -- President, Chief Executive Officer and Director
So let me try to emphasize this. Today, for smartphone, for high end to some of the mainstream where transition from eMMC to UFS. So that portion UFS we're going to grow and depend on one of the major primary phone NAND makers. And we believe they are already showing the momentum in last year, now they are repacked, moving for UFS 2.1. That portion we feel very comfortable.
Regarding eMMC. So eMMC is going to stay in the value line of a smartphone, also a portion of the mainstream, and it could be in China and also in India (ph) . That portion, I think we have our old partner from Korea that because they are transitioning majority portion into UFS. So that portion I think we were down compared to last year. However, this year it's quite stable. However, we see great momentum regarding from China module makers probably around six to seven customers, they are ramping now quickly for the low end smartphone, as well as for set-top box. That portion would create great momentum for us to grow eMMC, especially from second half of this year, that's also in Xiaomi smartphone. So we feel very accountable to grow with China module maker for eMMC and grow UFS with one of the NAND maker for second half of this year.
Karl Ackerman -- Cowen -- Analyst
Thank you.
Operator
Thank you. Your next question comes from the line of Craig Ellis from B. Riley FBR. Please go ahead.
Craig Ellis -- B. Riley FBR -- Analyst
Yes, thanks for taking the question. And Wallace and Riyadh, good afternoon and it's very nice to be back in touch again. My first question was related to the SSD controller business. You were clear on outlook dynamics for the second quarter and some of the limited visibility that exists for the second half but, can you help us understand in the second quarter by the degree to which you'd expect the OEM business to perform versus the module maker business. Do you expect them to grow equally or one materially faster than the other?
Wallace C. Kou -- President, Chief Executive Officer and Director
So regarding the SSD controller rebouncing, we feel very comfortable with the high confidence we're going to have a strong rebound about 25% or so revenue growing same quarter. The main reason because our major project in PC OEMs start to ramp. But also the module maker from most of it in China and Taiwan because the NAND price is relatively stable in the second quarter. They start to procure much more NAND from NAND maker. Since NAND is still staying in the actual inventory demands much bigger than -- supply much bigger than demand. So we take advantage all the NAND maker wants to sell through their actual inventory. Because we are in the leading position, providing all the different solution for customer that's why the demands on our side become much higher.
Frankly speaking, we don't have enough resource to support all the project we can have, we can get today. But we believe in the second quarter those module makers, OEM all grow. I cannot say equally 50-50, or 65 -- 55-45 but those all grow much stronger than first quarter.
Craig Ellis -- B. Riley FBR -- Analyst
That's helpful and then two follow-ups to that. First, regarding last statement about the demand that your customers are placing on you for help with the work that you have -- do you expect to improve your position to meet demand in the back half of the year? And somewhat related to that, with respect to the opportunity to convert 250 million client HDDs to NAND, how much progress do you think industry will make on that opportunity in this year? And what do you think is possible next year given where NAND flash prices are relative to HDDs now?
Wallace C. Kou -- President, Chief Executive Officer and Director
In our view PC OEM really aggressively tried to replace the HDD with the SSD. I think on commercial lines, almost 80%, 90% already is SSD but consumer line because they have a lot of dual drives, allow the a consumer line with dual drive, they would keep at least one HDD and one SDD, but we also see some of desktop will start to replace HDD with SSD. So when the NAND price its evolved (ph) deeply even to 2020 we see QLC NAND really become more important. I say from 2020, almost all NAND maker is going to offer 96-layer QLC, that is going to trigger another price decline price chart, where there's a deep. We believe there will be a good momentum for -- we see the SSD moving.
For portable SSD, it's very interesting. We just start to see the momentum and a lot of customers talk about looking for solutions to replace external HDD. That portion is around 150 million units today and I think they will be taking another three to five years to replace external HDD. And when the majority will require QLC and majority need at least a four terabyte for external solution. That will also help NAND maker to really allocate their assets NAND inventory for external solutions. I think that would be the momentum for the next few years to focus on and that could be a great growth potential for us to sell our controller to NAND makers, as well as to module makers.
Riyadh Lai -- Chief Financial Officer
Craig, let me also add, when you look at client hard disk drives, they are generally in three segments, the computing segment, consumer electronics, and external storage. In the PC segment, the conversion to SSD is already pretty meaningful, but the conversion to SSDs in consumer electronics and external storage are still very low. So we expect a lot of the replacement of hard disk drives to be happening on these two other segments, consumer electronics and external storage over the next few years.
So when you look at our conversion by capacity on the hard disk drive side, over the last few years it's been one capacity category SSD after another becoming cheaper than hard disk drives. First the 128 gigabyte SSDs and the 256 gigabyte SSDs, and today the OEM price of a 512 gigabyte SSD is already quite comparable to the price of hard disk drive. So even very soon one terabyte SSD could be as cheaper than a hard disk drive and already for consumers you can go to Amazon.com and buy one terabyte SSDs for about $100, or a little bit more than that and we talk about retail price. So the market for SSDs will continue to grow rapidly and the pace of its growth will be larger depending on how fast NAND prices continue to come down and at what rate hard disk drives continue to be replaced.
Craig Ellis -- B. Riley FBR -- Analyst
That's a very helpful color. And if I could ask one more -- I would just inquire about the OpEx as we look through the year. My sense is that as you presented the financial results pro forma without FCI, that all of the operating expense relative to that business is out of the forward looking model. But is there any efficiency enhancement or optimization that would come either in the second quarter or in the back half of the year related to that divestiture? Thank you, gentlemen.
Riyadh Lai -- Chief Financial Officer
Yes, that's a good -- that's for our divestiture of FCI. The operating expense over FCI runs roughly 4$million to $4.5 million quarterly, per quarter. In Q1, it's been -- it was a little higher than the normal because of project expenses and other R&D expenditures but on a normalized quarterly basis our FCI operating expense is about $4 million to $4.5 million. So once this deal is done then we expect this deal to be closed in the second quarter we will be running our business without that. And so the benefit would be coming through from higher operating margin, as well as improvements in our EPS.
Craig Ellis -- B. Riley FBR -- Analyst
Thank you.
Operator
Thank you. Your next question comes from the line of Anthony Stoss from Craig-Hallum. Please go ahead.
Anthony Stoss -- Craig-Hallum -- Analyst
Hi guys. A couple of questions. Riyadh, namely your full year guidance to be approximately the same as the $530 million you did in 2018. Are you assuming nothing from FCI, or just the six months that it's going to be under your wing in terms of that view of $530 million? And then also, I'd love to hear a little bit more on the SSD and the client-side design wins, perhaps for the second half of the year on a percentage basis more than you had in the second half of '18? And then my last question would be you mentioned of shipping embedded SSDs to a handful of U.S. customers, low volume later on this year, can you expand about upon what the opportunity might be with U.S. customers in 2020? Thanks.
Riyadh Lai -- Chief Financial Officer
Let me start with the first question and turn over to Wallace for the two other questions. In terms of our non-GAAP revenue for this year, we're talking about that despite our limited sales visibility for the second half of the year, until we have better visibility it is reasonably likely that our full-year revenue could be approximately the same as last year. And we are looking at -- when I talk about this we're talking about in apples-to-apples basis. So this year was without FCI being our non-GAAP revenue and for last year we'll be also excluding our FCI revenue.
Wallace C. Kou -- President, Chief Executive Officer and Director
Okay. Regarding SSD business, I think from client side we are experiencing tremendous demands from customers right now, from both NAND partner as well as some module makers. We also have some direct requirements on PC-OEM. So we are pretty confident in overall client SSD development also market trend in our product position. Regarding we managing our enterprise SSD controller, we are going to ship low volume to a few U.S. customers, that is correct, where we can hardly name the customer because we are very confident, they have been working for almost more than one year and we know exactly what they're looking for. But they're going to try different type of storage application and we definitely looking forward to grow the business in 2020 in both the U.S. and China markets.
Anthony Stoss -- Craig-Hallum -- Analyst
Wallace, do you think that the U.S. opportunity is material to Silicon Motion?
Wallace C. Kou -- President, Chief Executive Officer and Director
I believe so. We are definitely looking for a long time in our strategy, that's why I put a focus. Have a full power roadmap to enter enterprise SSD controller business.
Anthony Stoss -- Craig-Hallum -- Analyst
And if I could just throw in one more question. Also more general for you, Wallace. Have you seen any material changes in your ASPs on SSD side, or any material changes in competition? I know you had highlighted -- you expect to actually grow share in the SSD client side. Thank you.
Wallace C. Kou -- President, Chief Executive Officer and Director
That's a very good question. As you know, when NAND price declined sharply, a lot of our module maker they cannot make profit. And that's why they also become very angry. If we can now really share the plan. So from time to time we need to reduce our price, our ASP. But from product mix, the bigger -- new high-end products coming that's why we have pretty good confidence to maintain our ASP because more PCIe, also we can offer PCIe Gen4 by end of this year. And so more high-end products coming and we also reduce some of our ASP for low-end SATA product line. That will help to share the plan for our customers but overall we think we can maintain the gross margin, maintain the ASP.
Anthony Stoss -- Craig-Hallum -- Analyst
Great. Thank you.
Operator
Thank you. Your next question comes from the line of Mehdi Hosseini from SIG. Please go ahead.
Mehdi Hosseini -- SIG -- Analyst
Yes. Thanks for taking my question. A couple of follow ups. Riyadh, did you say that the year end guide that you provided excludes the divestitures?
Riyadh Lai -- Chief Financial Officer
Our full year revenue for our non-GAAP excludes FCI. And so when we compare that to last year we're also looking at it on an apples-to-apples basis, so excluding FCI. So you can see that in our financials as part of our 6-K earnings release, we provide our GAAP numbers as well as our non-GAAP and the reconciliation for that. There you can see how we exclude FCI for both Q1 and also the prior quarters.
Mehdi Hosseini -- SIG -- Analyst
Sure. And then a couple of follow ups for Wallace. Given your rather a more constructive outlook for the second half, especially for SSD solution and including Open Channel, when would you start procuring NAND, especially if you think NAND prices are going to go sideways in the second half? At what point in Q2 would you take advantage of opportunity and for Q4 your own products shipping in the second half?
Wallace C. Kou -- President, Chief Executive Officer and Director
Yeah, of course. So Shannon business -- so for BAT project our procurement goes through one of the SSD manufacture partner. This is one of the largest manufacture partner in the world. So they would procure NAND and manufacture for us. For non-BAT customer, we will procure ourselves. So every quarter we procure NAND from the select NAND partner.
Mehdi Hosseini -- SIG -- Analyst
So in that context, would you wait till like June to take advantage of prices before they stabilize or have you already started?
Wallace C. Kou -- President, Chief Executive Officer and Director
No, we gave a rolling forecast. Every month we have rolling -- six month rolling forecast to our manufacture partner. So price negotiation every three months. We have price negotiation for the NAND price.
Riyadh Lai -- Chief Financial Officer
So Mehdi, to put it another way. We don't speculate -- the way we manage our business is not to speculate on NAND prices going up or going down, it's more -- we're buying for the businesses that we have, a quarter in that.
Mehdi Hosseini -- SIG -- Analyst
Sure. You just said over the past year-and-a-half, or rather two years, due to declining NAND prices we were speculating demand elasticity and that hasn't happened. So how is it different now?
Wallace C. Kou -- President, Chief Executive Officer and Director
No. I think in the past the Shannon business because it is more and is very dynamic. Sometimes, our Shannon operation procurement make mistake. So we have some inventory cannot sell-through, that's why they hurt our overall gross margin. And now we believe this arrangement we said that Tier-one manufacture partner globally they would help us first to procure very attractive price for the NAND. Secondly, we don't need to take a risk for inventory and that will help us to deal with the BAT major customer.
Mehdi Hosseini -- SIG -- Analyst
Got it. Very clear. Thank you. And just one quick for Riyadh, I'm just trying to better understand how you plan. Let's say in a worst case scenario if the open channel or incremental opportunities were not to materialize, how are you contemplating for your cost into 2020? I'm asking this so that we could better understand a worst case scenario given how you have adjusted and opportunities that could present to you, so what if they don't happen. What's the worst case scenario with OpEx?
Riyadh Lai -- Chief Financial Officer
Well, we have our OpEx related to our controller programs and those we have a very clear roadmap in terms of our projects, our technology, the customers and what we need to do to deliver on those objectives from an engineering and headcount perspective. And so that roadmap will continue. Separately, we have our business plans relating to our Shannon SSDs and headcount related to that and so the headcount related to that will be dependent on how our business continues to progress.
Wallace C. Kou -- President, Chief Executive Officer and Director
Let me add a comment. To remember, our enterprise controller support dual-mode, one is open channels, the other is standard NVMe. So for our engagement with BAT, they needed both SSD solution, I mean open channel as well as NVMe standard. For other customers, we also can sell the same solution and load a different firmware as standard NVMe. So the development really is no risk for our effort regarding headcount or the capital expense.
Mehdi Hosseini -- SIG -- Analyst
Great. Thank you. Thanks for all the details.
Operator
Thank you. Your next question comes from the line of Harish (ph) from Needham & Company. Please ask your question.
Harish [ph] -- Needham & Company -- Analyst
Hey, guys. Thanks for taking my question. So I just wanted to transition over to this megatrends. So when it comes to 5G, how do you expect that to affect your business? Just a little bit of color in that would be appreciated.
Wallace C. Kou -- President, Chief Executive Officer and Director
Yeah, we don't see that 5G going to empower our business but we do see that 5G, the leading chipset maker like Qualcomm, the Snapdragon A65, they're going to move to UFS 3.0 that demand a higher performance and our (inaudible) controller is ready which is a way for any smartphone maker, they are going to take for the Qualcomm next generation more than the AP. But for the data center, they're supposed to have a really new demand for data center change overall infrastructure to support 5G because it will use higher bandwidth, have more people to use the Big Data.
